concepts.definition: A set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can unilaterally change their strategy and get a better payoff.
concepts.application: Look for stable states where no one wants to deviate.

concepts.definition: A state where no resource can be reallocated to make one individual better off without making at least one individual worse off.
concepts.application: Evaluate if the outcome is socially optimal or can be improved for everyone.

concepts.definition: A strategy that produces the highest payoff for a player regardless of what the other players do.
concepts.application: Always play a dominant strategy if one exists.

concepts.definition: A mathematical representation of a situation in which each participant's gain or loss of utility is exactly balanced by the losses or gains of the utility of the other participants.
concepts.application: Recognize that your gain is the opponent's loss. Collaboration is impossible.

concepts.definition: Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement. The most advantageous alternative course of action a party can take if negotiations fail and an agreement cannot be reached.
concepts.application: Know your walk-away point. Do not accept a deal worse than your BATNA.

concepts.definition: The process of reasoning backward in time, from the end of a problem or situation, to determine a sequence of optimal actions.
concepts.application: Look forward to the end of the game and reason backward to the present.

games.name: Prisoner's Dilemma
games.description: Two rational agents might not cooperate, even if it appears that it is in their best interest to do so.
games.payoff_structure: T > R > P > S (T=Temptation, R=Reward, P=Punishment, S=Sucker)
games.insights: In a single shot, Defect is dominant. In iterated versions, cooperation can emerge (e.g., Tit-for-Tat).

games.name: Chicken (Hawk-Dove)
games.description: A game of conflict between two players in which the optimal strategy depends on the strategy of the opponent: if the opponent yields, be aggressive; if the opponent is aggressive, yield.
games.payoff_structure: DC > CC > CD > DD (Best is to defect while other coops, worst is both defect/crash)
games.insights: The key is commitment. If you can convincingly signal you will not swerve, the opponent must swerve.

games.name: Battle of the Sexes
games.description: A coordination game where two players share a main goal (spend time together) but have different preferred sub-goals (e.g., Opera vs. Football).
games.insights: Communication or focal points are required to solve the coordination problem.

games.name: Stag Hunt
games.description: A game that describes a conflict between safety and social cooperation. Hunting a stag requires cooperation; hunting a hare can be done alone.
games.insights: Trust is essential. If you trust the other to hunt stag, you should too. If not, play safe.

heuristics.description: A solution that people will tend to use in the absence of communication because it seems natural, special, or relevant to them.
Start by cooperating, then do whatever the opponent did in the previous round. It is nice, retaliating, forgiving, and clear.
Cooperate until the opponent defects once, then defect forever.
